Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing the behavior of microscopic particles. However, it is not a theory that is easy to understand. This is partly because it is a non-classical theory, in the sense that it does not fit into the classical framework of logic and set theory. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to quantum theory. This approach does not presuppose any analytical structure, and it is therefore applicable to any non-classical theory. We show that quantum mechanics is equivalent to a category of the same type as the category of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces. This provides a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is independent of any particular analytical framework.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comprehensive analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to the essential elements required for parasitism, and that the genome is reduced in size and gene content. These findings suggest that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan was accompanied by a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content. This is the first time to our knowledge that a myxozoan genome has been sequenced, and our results provide a unique resource for future studies of the evolution of the Myxozoa and the origin of parasitism.

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused a global health crisis. The SARS-CoV-2 virus is able to evade the host immune response by blocking the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). In this study, we show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this evasion mechanism. We demonstrate that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that is essential for the nuclear import of ISGs. We also show that a simple mutation in Orf6 abolishes its ability to block nuclear import and impair IFN signaling. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used by other pathogens to evade the host immune response. This knowledge could be used to develop new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of a growing population. This study shows that the variability of maize production will increase substantially in the future, with the risk of simultaneous production losses becoming much higher. This will have important implications for the stability of global grain trade and international grain prices, which will be of great concern to the poor. Our results highlight the importance of breeding for heat tolerance, which will be essential to mitigate the negative impacts of climate change on maize production. This will be especially important in the tropics, where the majority of maize production will have to be increased to meet the growing demand.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in herbivore feces. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivore species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These findings suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that large herbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for the management of large herbivore populations in African savanna and elsewhere.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the US economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the survey also reveals substantial heterogeneity in the impact of the pandemic. Some businesses are more vulnerable than others, and some are better positioned to weather the crisis. We also find that many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, we find that many small businesses are planning to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, on the order of tens of thousands of tons. This is due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris in the open ocean, which involve the fast nano-fragmentation of plastic debris into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the formation of the solar system and the early solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for understanding the formation of the solar system and the early solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of all living organisms. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing, a form of maternal care in which the mother provides food to the offspring after birth. This suggests that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This finding has implications for the evolution of mammalian reproductive strategies and the evolution of the placenta. It also has implications for the evolution of domestication and allomaternal care. Finally, it has implications for the evolution of human reproduction. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproduction in mammals and humans. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of domestication and allomaternal care.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected to each other by a network of short-range and long-range connections. The network is critical for the endothelium to communicate with the rest of the body. The network is also critical for the endothelium to control the functions of the blood vessels.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to provide open access to data that can be used to monitor the pandemic and its impact on society. The API provides access to a wide range of signals, including traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in human health is still being elucidated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host and the host environment. The gut microbiome is also influenced by the host diet, which is a major determinant of the host’s health. The host diet can influence the composition of the microbiome by altering the composition of the food consumed. The host can also influence the microbiome by producing metabolites that are excreted in the feces. These metabolites can influence the composition of the microbiome, and in some cases, they can even be used by the microbiome to compete with other microbes for nutrients. In this study, we investigate the role of anaerobic fungi in the microbiome of herbivores. We find that anaerobic fungi are important contributors to the microbiome of herbivores and that they produce a variety of natural products that could be used to influence the composition of the microbiome. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of the microbiome in human health and for the development of new strategies for manipulating the microbiome to influence health.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We demonstrate that high-anxious animals are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat and that this low probability to become dominant is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further show that microinfusion of specific mitochondrial inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduces social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious animals. Finally, we show that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, which enhances brain energy metabolism, prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for various applications. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

The PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway is frequently mutated in human cancer, and its activation is associated with resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. Here, we show that the activation of this pathway protects cancer cells from oxidative stress and ferroptosis through the induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a key regulator of lipid metabolism. We also show that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction results in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway is a potential therapeutic target for cancer treatment in which ferroptosis induction is desired. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and the most important risk factor for heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are widely used in clinical practice. However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is mediated by the STIM/ORAI pathway. Our findings have important implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet been effective in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP has halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area was stable, but declined in two ecoregions—the Coast Range and Cascades—along with early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will require a continued focus on the development of older-forest structure and the maintenance of early-seral ecosystems.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is essential to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. We used a combination of in silico and in vitro experiments to screen a library of 1,000 compounds. The best candidates were then tested in vivo against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The best compound designed by us is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is more accessible, exhibits higher binding affinity to the ribosome, and is more soluble than the best compound identified by screening. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work demonstrates the potential of computational approaches to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish are a famous example of adaptive radiation, with 175 species inhabiting the lake. The species flock is one of the most diverse and species-rich in the world, and the lake is one of the most diverse freshwater ecosystems on Earth. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the region, which shows that the lake has been much lower in the past, and that the species flock evolved in a much drier environment. The lake has been much higher in the past, and we suggest that this has led to the formation of new ecological niches, which has enabled the rapid adaptive radiation of the species flock.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the biological effects of this exposure on sleep are unknown. Here we compare the effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) with reading a printed book in the hours before bedtime. We found that reading an LE-eBook delayed the circadian clock, suppressed melatonin, and reduced the next-morning alertness and performance. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These findings also highlight the importance of the circadian system in the regulation of sleep and the need for further research on the effects of this technology on sleep and health. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are of terrestrial origin. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the magnetic grains and microspherules are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating that the magnetic grains and microspherules are of continental origin. The magnetic grains and microspherules are from a single impact event, as shown by their rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in the development of a variety of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but is accompanied by a shift in the immune response toward a Th1 response.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Our results show that the origin of beetles coincides with the first appearance of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls, and that these genes triggered a series of adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles. Thus, the evolution of beetles appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. This study provides insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals. (Less)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our findings have implications for the evolution of human culture and the role of social learning in the emergence of new technologies.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE is also a major protein in the brain, where it is produced by astrocytes. We found that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, accelerating the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of APOE in AD risk. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of APOE in the brain.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is the only known natural solid core in the solar system. The inner core is a unique natural laboratory for studying the crystallization process of the core. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. This study provides a solution to the long-standing paradox of the inner core nucleation mechanism. The results provide a new perspective on the crystallization process of the core. They also provide a new understanding of the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. The results are expected to be of great significance to the study of the core and the origin of the solar system. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels, was compared between marijuana abusers and controls. Compared with controls, marijuana abusers had significantly attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine D2 receptor availability (reflecting DA increases). The attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal DVs, are consistent with decreased brain reactivity to the DA stimulation in marijuana abusers that might contribute to their negative emotionality (increased stress reactivity and irritability) and addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the urgency to investigate effects of chronic marijuana in the human brain.

The human brain’s processing of language is a central cognitive function, but its neural mechanisms remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also predict the majority of the explainable variance in the brain’s responses to language. This suggests that the most powerful artificial neural networks may be capturing the essence of language processing in the human brain. We also find that the most powerful models generalize across datasets and imaging modalities, and that model architecture appears to contribute to neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the most powerful artificial neural networks may be a powerful tool for understanding the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many fields, including computer vision, speech recognition, and natural language processing. However, the stability of DL has been a major concern. In this paper, we show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that there are problems that cannot be solved by stable neural networks. We also introduce a new algorithm, FIRENET, that is stable and can solve the inverse problem with high accuracy. This work is a step toward the stability of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited as evidence for this claim. The experiment’s design flaws were not noticed at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of the phenomenon. The flaws are discussed as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining a study in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. The disease is characterized by the loss of sensation and the formation of lepromatous and lepromatous-like lesions. The cause of the reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon, which is characterized by the formation of diffuse lesions, is unknown. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, a pathogen that causes diffuse lepromatous leprosy and Lucio’s phenomenon. The genomes of the two pathogens are similar in size and synteny, and the two pathogens have lost many genes that are required for amino acid synthesis. M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to infect the nervous system, and therefore may also be neuropathogenic. Our findings suggest that the two pathogens have diverged from a common ancestor and that they have retained many genes that are required to cause the same disease. This suggests that they have maintained the ability to cause the same disease for a long time. This is important for understanding the evolution of the disease and for the development of effective therapies.

The evolution of entanglement is a key question in quantum many-body physics. It is also a fundamental problem in statistical physics, as it is the origin of thermodynamics. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement with numerical data. Our work provides a general framework for the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems. It also opens the door to the study of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit in nonintegrable systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been devastating, and the search for a vaccine is ongoing. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codons. This vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In addition, the furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine candidate generated high levels of spike IgG antibody responses and plaque reduction neutralization titers in hamsters. Upon challenge with wild-type virus, the vaccine candidate reduced lung challenge viral titers, resulted in undetectable virus in the brain, and protected hamsters from almost all SARS-CoV-2–associated weight loss. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This vaccine candidate may be a valuable addition to the arsenal of COVID-19 vaccines. (Read more: https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-03600-0)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was the longest and most devastating of the three pandemics. It led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the Second Pandemic plague is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that it was spread by rats. However, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the primary vectors of the Second Pandemic plague. This finding challenges the assumption that rats were the primary vectors of the Second Pandemic plague, and it has implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of the Second Pandemic. Our results also suggest that the vector of the Second Pandemic plague was different from the vector of the first plague pandemic (13–18th centuries), which led to the Black Death (1347–1353). This finding has implications for our understanding of the history of plague in Europe. Finally, our results suggest that the vector of the Second Pandemic plague was different from the vector of the third plague pandemic (19th century), which led to the current plague pandemic. This finding has implications for our understanding of the history of plague in the 20th century.

The evolution of brain size is a topic of great interest, but it is not the only one. The number of neurons is the brain’s basic computational unit, and it is important to understand how it has changed through evolution. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The HSP90 chaperone family is implicated in a variety of cellular processes, including cell growth and death. TRAP1 is a member of the HSP90 family that is found predominantly in mitochondria. TRAP1 is considered to be an anticancer target, but current inhibitors cannot distinguish between HSP90 and TRAP1, making their utility as probes of TRAP1-specific function questionable. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, which is the network of filaments that provides the cell with shape and regulates many cellular processes. Actin filaments are also the main components of the motility machinery of many cellular processes, such as cell division and cell migration. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is therefore critical for many cellular processes. However, how it does so is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments, and we show that this process is enhanced by mechanical stress. This finding has implications for our understanding of ADF/cofilin’s function in cells. It also has implications for our understanding of the role of mechanical stress in cellular processes. Finally, it has implications for our understanding of the role of ADF/cofilin in cellular processes.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. The present study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the etiology of obesity and diabetes. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by the gut microbiota. Future studies should investigate the effects of fructose on feeding behavior in animal models and in humans with a focus on the role of the gut microbiota. These studies may help elucidate the mechanisms by which fructose may contribute to the development of obesity and diabetes. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the history of the Malagasy people. We find that the Malagasy people are a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The settlement history of Madagascar is complex, with a recent arrival of Malagasy people, but also a history of independent colonization from Africa and Asia. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique island in the Indian Ocean. However, the results of previous experiments are controversial, and some have suggested that emotional contagion is not possible in the real world. Our results suggest that it is. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis in cells. The presence of chemical modifications in the sequence of mRNAs can have profound effects on the rate of translation. In this work, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the sequence of an mRNA can modestly alter the rate of translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ in the sequence of an mRNA can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in the sequence of an mRNA can have a significant impact on the rate of translation. This work also provides a structural basis for the incorporation of Ψ in the sequence of an mRNA. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better physical and mental health, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust across a wide range of sociodemographic factors, and they are also robust over time. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology. The aquatic mammals are the only group of mammals that have evolved to live in the water, and they are the only group of mammals that have evolved to live in the water in large numbers. We show that the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in the aquatic mammals, and that this is consistent with the aquatic mammals being driven to an optimum size by the energetic demands of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that the mouse airway cell line is a useful model for studying the temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus. We demonstrate that the mouse airway cell line exhibits a more efficient antiviral defense response at core body temperature than at nasal cavity temperature. We also show that the mouse airway cell line is a useful model for studying the role of the type I interferon antiviral response in rhinovirus infection. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus and suggest that the mouse airway cell line is a useful model for studying the role of the type I interferon antiviral response in rhinovirus infection. The type IV pili (T4P) of bacteria are major surface adhesins that are involved in a wide range of biological processes, including biofilm formation and pathogenicity. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses T4P for surface sensing. This process is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system, which regulates the production of cAMP and the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The Chp system is activated by the mechanical activity of T4P, which is required for the long-term attachment of P. aeruginosa to surfaces. Our findings suggest that T4P are not only involved in surface-specific motility, but also as a mechanosensitive sensor that regulates the expression of genes involved in surface-induced processes and pathogenicity. This study thus provides a mechanistic explanation for the role of T4P in bacterial surface sensing and virulence. It also suggests that T4P can be a target for the development of new antibacterial strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and this trend is expected to continue. However, the consequences of this increase for the quality of surface waters are poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture should be reduced, and that the current regulatory framework should be improved worldwide.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in the environment. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human infections are rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study is a step toward the development of strategies to mitigate the risk of SARS-CoV-2 transmission to wildlife and to prevent the emergence of new variants that are adapted to animal reservoirs. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern. The paper examines the reasons for the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam, and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of much research. However, the role of Aβ in the earliest stages of AD is still debated. Here, we show that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors, which may be responsible for the initiation of the AD-related immune response. This study provides a new perspective on the role of the Aβ hypothesis in AD pathogenesis, and it may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how the protein folds. The most common approach is to study the folding of a small protein, which is assumed to fold in a similar way to large proteins. However, the folding of large proteins is more complex, and it is not yet clear how the folding of a large protein is similar to or different from that of a small protein. We studied the folding of the maltose binding protein, which is a large protein, and found that it folds through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme RppH, which is inactivated by Np4, is the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs in Escherichia coli cells experiencing stress. We also show that RppH prefers to decape Np4-capped RNAs over their capped counterparts, and that the enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the immune dysfunction during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of citrulline in the treatment of other conditions associated with immune dysfunction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system evolves at a critical rate, which is independent of its internal state, and in which external perturbations do not change the rate of evolution. SOC is observed in a variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, fire fronts, neural networks, and fracture processes. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks under mechanical stress. Therefore, it is difficult to apply diamond in devices. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This work provides a new way to tailor the properties of diamond. It also provides a new perspective for the study of the relationship between the bandgap and the elastic properties of diamond. It is expected to promote the development of diamond-based devices and applications. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and will be of particular interest to those studying the male–female reproductive axis.

Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the role of viruses in the human microbiome has been difficult to study, because of the lack of a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The database is freely available to the scientific community.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. The dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) is a new instrument that can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosol and cloud properties. This instrument is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. We present the dual-FOV HSRL and demonstrate its capability to investigate aerosol–cloud interaction. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of intense debate. The temperature of the surface of the Earth in the Archean, the earliest period of Earth history, has been estimated to be as high as 80 °C. This estimate is based on the isotopic composition of marine cherts, which is thought to reflect the temperature of the oceans. However, this estimate has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a new method for determining the temperature of the early Earth, based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that the temperature of the early Earth decreased over geological time. This finding is consistent with previous estimates based on isotopic evidence and provides new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous system and heart. The K+ channel KCNB1 is the gene product of the cardiac-specific K+ channel, the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel. The BK channel is important for the normal function of the heart and is also involved in the pathophysiology of cardiac arrhythmia. The BK channel is unique in that it lacks a classic intracellular activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of K+ channels. It also provides a theoretical basis for the development of drugs that can selectively block the BK channel. This study may also provide a theoretical basis for the development of drugs that can selectively block the BK channel.

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the world today. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion, a process that has been the subject of intense study for over a century. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces, a paradigm shift in our understanding of this process.

However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks under mechanical stress. Therefore, it is difficult to apply diamond in devices. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be closed, without phonon instability. This work provides a new way to control the properties of diamond. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection in the context of ambient humidity. They also suggest that humidity may be a potential target for the development of therapeutic strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection. This article is protected by copyright. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the brain’s activity during the construction of such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the activity of multiple regions in the superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices increases with each successive word in a sentence, but decreases when words merge into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a bottom-up parser that merges words into phrases, which in turn merge into phrases, and so on, until a sentence is complete. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in a wide variety of processes, including development and cancer. The pathway is regulated by two key components, Axin and β-catenin. Axin is a scaffold that inhibits the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and gene activation. We show here that the two forms of Axin are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which allows for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway. This is a common feature in vertebrates, which may be used to distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving the ventral tegmental area (VTA), the dopamine neurons of which are inhibited by LH neurons. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of the VTA or dopamine neurons, suggesting that this is a critical downstream circuit element. Surprisingly, we find that this system is not involved in the hunger or satiety mechanisms that govern normal feeding. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may help to elucidate the mechanisms of overeating and obesity and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of these conditions. Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in the soil is the main factor limiting crop yields. The use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture is a promising strategy to increase the nitrogen supply to the crop. However, the use of these bacteria is limited by the fact that they are free-living soil bacteria that can potentially compete with the crop for nitrogen. Here, we demonstrate that the use of a bacterial signal can control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil and prevent them from competing with the crop. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of bacterial signals in the control of nitrogen-fixing bacteria. This work is expected to be of interest to the scientific community working on nitrogen-fixing bacteria and nitrogen in agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Peruvian Amazon is the most deforested tropical forest in the world. The Peruvian government has invested in remote-sensed monitoring of deforestation, but the effectiveness of these systems in deterring deforestation is unknown. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse in shape and size, but all are part of the animal’s body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. We demonstrate that the spider’s web is an external ear that is able to detect and localize the direction of sound. The spider’s web is not constrained by the body and can be easily extended to 10,000 times the size of the spider itself. This study provides a unique model for studying the outsourcing and supersizing of sensing and for designing novel acoustic flow detectors. It also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the auditory system and the role of outsourcing in the evolution of animal hearing.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are often considered separately. We show that the health benefits of reducing air pollution are much larger than previously thought, and that the climate benefits are much larger than previously thought. We also show that the health benefits of reducing aerosols are much larger than previously thought, and that the climate benefits are much larger than previously thought. This is because aerosols mask the anthropogenic warming, and removing aerosols liberates the warming. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global population. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the virus. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that this engineered RBD may be a promising candidate for a subunit vaccine.

The role of ALK in the development of human neuroblastoma is well established. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK are activated by zebrafish ALKALs. We further show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, a neural crest-derived tissue. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. These findings provide a basis for further studies on the role of ALK/LTK in the development of human neuroblastoma. They also suggest that ALK/LTK signaling may be a therapeutic target in neuroblastoma. Finally, our findings may be relevant to other neural crest-derived tissues. The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have provided key evolutionary insights into its emergence, but the number of genomes from this period are too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Bronze Age to the Early Middle Ages, which allowed us to explore correlations between temporal, geographical, and genetic distance. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. These data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—is a key feature of patriarchy. In this work, we show that HM predicts men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. We also show that HM predicts unique variance in evaluations of Trump, over and above the social and prejudiced attitudes that are associated with his support. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical question for the future of the global food system. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to the release of massive amounts of SOC to the atmosphere. However, the extent to which this trend can be reversed is unknown. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC stored in the mineral soil. These practices include reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, and rotational grazing of pastures. These results highlight the potential for well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon on a global scale. This study also highlights the importance of including perennial vegetation in agricultural systems to mitigate climate change. This study is a step toward the development of climate-smart agricultural practices that can help feed the world.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread in humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential, which included SARS-CoV-2. We also created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the data and prioritize viruses of interest. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards offered by Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) is a blood-red nectar. We show that the red color of this nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid with potential pharmaceutical applications.

The history of Europe is marked by complex demographic processes, which have shaped the genetic structure of the modern population. However, the genetic history of the period between the migrations of the 5th century and the arrival of the Vikings in the 8th century is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a panel of 41 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. We show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. This heterogeneity is also reflected in the set of functional variants, which indicates that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the replication of DNA in the nucleus. This process is carried out by the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) enzyme, which is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications on the replication process. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it is possible to evolve ribozymes that can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template, but it has not been possible to evolve a ribozyme that can replicate RNA. Here, we report the development of an improved ribozyme that can replicate RNA, and we demonstrate that this improved ribozyme can replicate RNA in a PCR-like manner. Thus, we have achieved the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—in the laboratory. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world.

The physical appearance of neighborhoods is a key aspect of urban life. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The clinical manifestations of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are similar, and the mortality rate is high. The current treatment is mainly supportive therapy. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can improve the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability to regulate copper content is therefore an important aspect of fungal physiology. The xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide compounds that bind copper. We show that these compounds are secreted, have antimicrobial properties, and impact copper content. The existence of the xanthocillin BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for this pathway in the regulation of copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the impact of metal homeostasis on fungal physiology and interactions with other organisms. The formation of silica polymorphs in a sedimentary environment is rare on Earth and on Mars. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous silica is a primary precipitate or its diagenesis product. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere, but the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new frost regimes. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this subset of cells is not well understood. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in a mouse model of transfer colitis, and that this defect was due to the inability of Th17 cells to induce the development of colitis-associated pathology. Th17 cells were also required for the development of a subset of Th1 cells, but not for the development of Th2 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important for the development of a subset of pathogenic Th1 cells. This may be important for the development of therapeutic strategies to target Th17 cells in inflammatory bowel disease.
