The role of the microbiota in vector-borne pathogen transmission is poorly understood. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the Ixodes scapularis tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the transmission of Anaplasma to the vector. We demonstrate that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will aid in the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Read more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary lineage that includes the modern bird family Pygostylia. However, the diversity of early branching members of this group is limited, which makes it difficult to understand the origin of the modern avian tail. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, which adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the role of individual processes in its evolution. Here we show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, due to the presence of pigments in their tissues. In some species, the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally present in the blood, gives them a characteristic green color. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans (frogs and toads), and that it is due to the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins, which we named biliverdin-binding serpins (BBS), are most similar to human antiproteases, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results provide evidence of the recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a molecular basis for the green color of anurans.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells are able to form a small population of cells that are responsible for the initiation and growth of the tumor. These cells are called cancer stem cells (CSCs). CSCs are characterized by their ability to self-renew and to give rise to the other cells in the tumor. In this study, we show that the HIF-dependent expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5) is important for the maintenance of the CSC phenotype in breast cancer cells. Our findings have implications for the treatment of breast cancer, as targeting ALKBH5 may be a strategy for the control of CSCs. This study also provides a mechanism for the role of ALKBH5 in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Thus, our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were made from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, and the extinction interval is 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction, and the recovery was protracted. These results will help to evaluate the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms for the extinction. The age model will also be used to evaluate the timing of recovery of the ecosystem, and to assess the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction. This work will advance our understanding of the causes and consequences of the most severe extinction event in Earth history.

The intestinal epithelium is the first line of defense against the environment, and intestinal inflammation is a major cause of morbidity and mortality. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays a critical role in the regulation of various biological processes. Here, we report that RORα is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We further demonstrate that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated NF-κB signaling is critical for the inflammatory response in the intestinal epithelium. Our findings suggest that RORα/HDAC3-mediated NF-κB signaling is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. This study provides a better understanding of the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune response of the host and of the vaccine. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with ACE2, the receptor for SARS-CoV-2, at 8.5 Å resolution. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has little effect on the structure of the protein, but does have a large effect on the conformation of the spike protein. We also show that the D614G mutation has little effect on the binding of the spike protein to the receptor, but does have a large effect on the conformational changes required for fusion. These results provide a basis for understanding the effect of the D614G mutation on the infectivity of the virus. This information will be useful in the development of vaccines and in the understanding of the effect of the D614G mutation on the transmissibility of the virus. (Read more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of an atom are its electronegativity and chemical hardness. These two properties are central in chemistry, and they are the basis of the chemical potential, which is the driving force of chemical reactions. We show that these two properties decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical properties of matter under extreme conditions.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the implications for the carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have the potential to reduce warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. However, the risk of more extreme fires is also high, and the implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems are not yet clear. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of human ignitions in future fire regimes.

The mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is one of the best-studied symbioses in the animal kingdom. The squid provides the symbiont with a specific glycan, which is metabolized by the bacteria to produce a light signal. We show here that the glycan is provided to the bacteria just before dusk, when the squid is about to start its daily activity. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiont in the squid’s crypts, which are the site of symbiosis. Finally, we show that the glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the acidification of the crypts, which is necessary for the bacteria to produce light. We propose that this is a general mechanism for the regulation of symbiosis, in which the provision of a specific nutrient modulates the conditions in the habitat of the symbiont. This, in turn, affects the stability of the mutualism.

The study of text data has become a central part of many fields, from social science to medicine. However, the study of text data is difficult because of the large number of documents and the diversity of topics. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a generative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives, many of which are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and is likely to be useful in many fields.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. However, this assumption is based on a single event, which is difficult to confirm. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were similar in the years preceding the introduction of the bacterium into Europe, and that the bacterium was reintroduced into Europe repeatedly, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This suggests that the bacterium was introduced into Europe via a different route.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of marine ecosystems. The sea star (asteroid) wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease that has recently spread along the Pacific coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by the sea star Asterias rubens. This is the first report of a sea star wasting disease caused by a virus.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of a single target that is effective in all patients is not possible. Here, we show that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling is effective in suppressing the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also suggest that IL-1 signaling may be important for the growth of AML cells. Thus, the results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to reconstruct the history of the Malagasy people. We find that the Malagasy people are a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The settlement history of Madagascar is complex, with a recent arrival of Malagasy people, but also a history of independent colonization from Africa and Asia. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique island in the Indian Ocean. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, providing a wealth of information on crop status and condition. However, this information is rarely used in agricultural decision-making. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is the main source of information on crop status in the US, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that this index outperforms official forecasts released midseason, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources.

Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to integrate information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to integrate information over time. Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of the evolution of all photosynthetic eukaryotes. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is not known. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in water-scarce regions. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the fifth ring of (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key step in this process. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This paper describes the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes the formation of the fifth ring of (bacterio)chlorophylls, and their evolution is discussed.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroactive protein kinase ASK1 has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest and warmest on record. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased substantially. We also find that the probability of dry precipitation years being also warm has increased. This finding is consistent with climate models, which show that human activities have increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the 2012–2014 drought in California. This finding has important implications for water management and climate change adaptation in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral phenotypes of autism-risk genes and may facilitate the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This study also provides a framework for the identification of the convergent targets and functions of autism-risk genes. The news media are a critical source of information for the public, and the content of the news is a key determinant of the public’s information environment. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the prevalence of negativity biases in the news. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. This work also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content, suggesting that the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads” may be overstated. The results also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that result in bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates is dependent on the release of aggregates from the cell. These findings provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that the use of Drosophila as a model for neurodegenerative diseases may be useful in the study of this process.

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits the function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit the generation of the potent lipid chemoattractant leukotriene B4 (LTB4). MTX potently inhibits the proinflammatory proteases plasmin, trypsin, and elastase to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. MTX potently inhibits the proinflammatory activity of LTA4H and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of LTA4H in the immune response to viral infection and the potential of MTX as a therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of viral infections in humans and animals. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and demonstrate that they are effective cellular target engagers. We also show that formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1/2, and for the development of SHMT-based therapeutics for cancer and other diseases. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by the aggregation of mutant proteins in the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brain. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. We observe that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. Thus, our results suggest that the metastable state may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. This may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for these diseases.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The Cretaceous is a key period in the evolution of flowering plants. The origin of the flowering plants is still poorly understood, and the Cretaceous is the period in which the first flowering plants appeared. The Cretaceous is also the period in which the first aquatic flowering plants appeared. The aquatic flowering plants are important because they are the ancestors of the modern flowering plants. The aquatic flowering plants are also important because they are the ancestors of the first land plants. The aquatic flowering plants are also important because they are the ancestors of the first plants that colonized land. The aquatic flowering plants are also important because they are the ancestors of the first plants that colonized the land-water interface.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that has been associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (63.9–99.7% genome coverage) from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models. This finding is important because it provides a direct measurement of the rate of climate change, which is needed to assess the impacts of climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, with tomorrow’s elderly reporting more pain than today’s elderly. This pattern is not seen for those with a bachelor’s degree, suggesting that the erosion of working-class life is having a negative impact on the health of the American population.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease highlights the need for effective treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of preclinical testing of potential antiviral treatments for emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. This article is protected by copyright. The mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is one of the best-studied symbioses in the animal kingdom. The squid provides the symbiont with a specific glycan, which is metabolized by the bacteria to produce a light signal. We show here that the glycan is provided to the bacteria just before dusk, when the squid is about to start its daily activity. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiont in the squid’s crypts, which are the site of symbiosis. Finally, we show that the glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the acidification of the crypts, which is required for the bacteria to produce light. This study suggests that the glycan is a nutrient that is provided to the bacteria at a specific time of the day, and that the catabolism of this nutrient is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with disproportionate impact on Black and Latino students. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, and that this can reduce suspension rates. The study also shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships is a strong predictor of student behavior, and that this can be improved through scalable intervention. These findings have implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this work, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcription of a lacZ reporter gene. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles. Intriguingly, the stalling profiles are correlated with the fidelity checkpoints and the transcriptional lesion bypass routes. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This article is protected by copyright. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first S protein cleavages in MERS-CoV. These mutations severely compromised virus infection, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the world’s population are a key driver of this problem. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 60% and that the effect was concentrated among the lowest-purchasing quartile of diners. These results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could make a significant contribution to reducing the environmental impact of the food system. This approach could be applied in other settings, including hospitals, schools, and workplaces. The results also suggest that it may be possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets without the need for more complex interventions. The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the surfaceome is a critical target for cancer therapy. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to study the surfaceome of a panel of six oncogene-expressing breast epithelial cells, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics, and find massive oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer biology and therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on the 2016 and 2020 elections. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has a large number of mutations, but the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion and/or immune suppression. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the severity of the COVID-19 disease. They also provide a foundation for the development of future therapeutics. (Read less)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can lead to cerebral edema, a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic induction of the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF)/CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) axis. We also show that CRFR1 signaling in astrocytes triggers the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), which in turn contribute to the development of edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 antagonists may be useful in the treatment of this condition. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The problem of selective inference is that we have “cherry picked” a dataset and are now trying to assess the strength of the associations that we have found. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human fibroblasts. The ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. These findings provide a useful tool for the study of the development of ECs and the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the ETV2-induced ETVECs may be used as a source of ECs for the generation of vascular networks in regenerative medicine. These findings also suggest that ETV2 may be a potential target for the treatment of vascular disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK are considered “orphan” RTKs because they do not have known physiological ligands. Here, we show that zebrafish have three genes encoding ligands for ALK and LTK. We demonstrate that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish eye and the skin. These experiments establish a physiological link between ALK and LTK and demonstrate that particular ligands activate LTK in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. These findings provide insights into the physiological roles of ALK and LTK and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cancer and other diseases. β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Accumulating evidence indicates that stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in regulating insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, using global STING knockout (STING−/−) and β-cell–specific STING knockout (STING-βKO) mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING−/− beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They are divided into two groups, the human and avian influenza viruses, which are genetically distinct. The avian influenza viruses are divided into two subtypes, the A/chicken/China/23991/2013 (H5N1) and the A/chicken/China/230101/2013 (H7N9). The H5N1 subtype is of particular concern because of its high pathogenicity for humans. The H7N9 virus is the most pathogenic H7N9 virus to date. The genetic basis of the pathogenicity of these viruses is unknown. Here, we identified a mechanism that might contribute to the pathogenicity of these viruses.

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a multistep process that is initiated by the disruption of the normal flow of blood in the arterial wall. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the role of people in increasing the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionately occurred in areas with higher fuel moisture, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

The physical appearance of neighborhoods is a key aspect of urban life. However, it is difficult to measure changes in the physical appearance of neighborhoods over time. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement, (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements, and (iii) neighborhoods that are physically close to the central business district and to other attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel (sTRP1) that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated dTRPγ ion channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents in Drosophila melanogaster. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. One of the most visible and devastating effects of climate change on coral reefs is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which leads to mass bleaching and the death of the coral host. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which in turn is a consequence of the metabolic stress imposed by heat stress. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors. These tumors trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn triggers the growth of the tumors. We also show that the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn triggers the growth of the tumors. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the understanding of the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors and for the development of therapeutic strategies to control the activity of JNK signaling in the intestine. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that the expression of ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is difficult to reconcile with the timing of the onset of deglaciation. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions at the start of deglaciation is a plausible trigger for the observed climate changes.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high stress levels, and that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the Mo-based oxide lead to a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water, and a full cell presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost, and the few remaining regenerative neurons are unable to respond to injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the C. elegans nervous system that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway known to mediate regeneration in other organisms. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that regulate regeneration in the adult nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create genetic diversity. In sexually reproducing organisms, recombination is essential for the formation of offspring with unique combinations of genes. In the past, we lacked the tools to precisely map the locations of recombination events in a natural population. Here, we use a population of monkeyflowers to precisely locate over 400,000 boundaries of historic crossovers or gene conversion tracts. The resulting map of recombination activity defines some 13,000 hotspots of varying strengths, interspersed with cold regions of undetectably low recombination. The general pattern is similar to that observed in yeast, as well as in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the human brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, which are active in a resting state. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, but the results have been difficult to interpret because of the large number of networks that have been identified. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early PD patients, but was activated during task performance in advanced PD. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. The 5′ cap structure is also found on some small RNAs, such as tRNA and rRNA. Here we show that 5′ NAD+ RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We propose that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This 5′ NAD+ cap could be the first of many additional cap structures that will be discovered in the future.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not fully understood. We hypothesized that epigenetic DNA-methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in blood cells are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me alterations at certain loci in blood cells are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These results suggest that DNA-me alterations at specific loci in blood cells are associated with glycemia for several years during the DCCT and may provide a potential epigenetic mechanism for metabolic memory. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that is characterized by a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence. This approach may be of particular interest in the light of the recent increase in the number of cases of alcohol dependence in the Western world.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these nitrogenous volatiles is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not known. Here we report the discovery of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of climate change. Here we show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is more sensitive to biodiversity loss at high and low temperatures, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the strength of species interactions. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of climate change and biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for understanding the impacts of environmental change on the services that ecosystems provide to society.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the hippocampus, which is involved in spatial memory. The precise organization of the MEC is not fully understood, and it is unclear whether the different types of neurons in MEC are organized in a topographically structured manner. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that the different types of neurons in MEC are organized in a topographically structured manner. Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for the flowering of the host plant and the flowering of the dodder parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed at which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. We show that people feel more connected to others who respond quickly to them, and that this signal is used by third-party listeners to assess the quality of the connection between two people. This finding has implications for our understanding of the neural mechanisms of social connection, as well as for the design of technologies that can help us feel more connected to others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is a specialized heart tissue that generates the heart rate. SAN cells are responsible for the generation of the heart rate and are characterized by a unique electrical and molecular architecture. The molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the molecular clock in SAN cells. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in SAN cells and is required for the maintenance of the molecular clock in SAN cells. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the control of SAN function. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the molecular basis of SAN dysfunction in human diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating plant resistance to insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance to the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense responses against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant stress tolerance and resistance to insect herbivores. These findings may also provide insights into the use of Si in agriculture to improve crop productivity and resistance to insect herbivores. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based therapeutics. Herein, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are critical design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plants. We also show that the delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures is dependent on the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biology and nanotechnology communities.

In this study, we show that small streams can be a significant source of nutrients to the world’s fifth largest lake. Our findings suggest that small streams may be a significant contributor to coastal eutrophication in large lakes, and that nutrient management efforts should consider the role of small streams in coastal areas. The study of the dynamics of complex networks is a central theme in modern science. In this article, we study the dynamics of a simple model of a network of chemical reactions, which is driven by an environment that makes strong thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This finding is of interest in the context of the search for “robust” states in complex networks, which are able to maintain their functionality in the presence of perturbations. Our results suggest that the extremization of environmental forcing may be a general mechanism for the emergence of robust states in complex networks.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of an antibody against the NMDA receptor can change the intrinsic properties of the cortex, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We also show that the same changes in the microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in the presence of a subthreshold amount of antibody. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by an autoimmune antibody. They also suggest that the presence of an antibody against the NMDA receptor may be a useful biomarker for the diagnosis of autoimmune encephalitis. The history of Earth’s climate is a history of abrupt warming and cooling events. The history of the C cycle is a history of the history of the Earth system. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. We further show that the event was linked to an increase in seafloor anoxia. These results provide insights into the history of the Earth system and the potential for future abrupt warming events. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies and programs that aim to reduce tropical deforestation. We recommend that the RSPO and other certification schemes consider the results of this study in their efforts to reduce tropical deforestation. This article is protected by copyright. The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis. It is essential for the regulation of the size and shape of the plasma membrane and the trafficking of the vacuole. The exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Read more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an organism is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles interact to determine sex. In some species, the sex of an individual can be determined by multiple alleles, but the sex of a species is determined by a single allele. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the sex of an individual can be determined by multiple alleles, but the sex of the species is determined by a single allele. This modularity of secondary sexual characteristics provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of reactive oxygen species. The retina is also challenged by the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that Fe levels impact the retina by promoting the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the United States. Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of food webs. In this study, we show that the evolution of the feeding strategy of siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is linked to the evolution of their tentacles. We show that the evolution of the morphology of the tentacles is linked to the evolution of the prey that they capture. This study contributes to understanding the evolution of the feeding strategies of predators, and the role that these strategies play in the development of food webs.

The human hand is a complex structure that has changed little in the last two million years. However, the evolution of the hand has been poorly understood because of a lack of fossil evidence for the transition from earlier to later hominins. Here we report the discovery of a hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene to recent hominin site of Hadar, Ethiopia, that shows a key derived feature of the hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, which is present in the hand of a 1.42-Myr-old East African hominin. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for our understanding of hominin evolution and the evolution of the human hand. It also has implications for the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the genus Homo.

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and demonstrate that they are effective cellular target engagers. We also show that formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1/2, and for the development of SHMT-based therapeutics for cancer and other diseases. The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for the expansion of arable land and the production of more food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. This alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
